pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 905, 240]]<|/det|>
0625/12 May/June 2018 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 312, 386, 327]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 890, 415]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 890, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 489, 555, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 578]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet. Electronic calculators may be used. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 99, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 622, 90]]<|/det|>
A length of cotton is measured between two points on a ruler.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 100, 875, 184]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 784, 214]]<|/det|>
When the length of cotton is wound closely around a pen, it goes round six times.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 224, 700, 282]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 295, 462, 312]]<|/det|>
What is the distance once round the pen?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 323, 720, 341]]<|/det|>
**A** 2.2cm **B** 2.6cm **C** 13.2cm **D** 15.6cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 369, 96, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 369, 919, 416]]<|/det|>
A ball is dropped in an evacuated tube. A series of photographs is taken at equal time intervals from the time of release. Another ball of the same size but twice the mass is also dropped in the same evacuated tube and photographed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 555, 446]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the motion of the heavier ball?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 457, 819, 820]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 99, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 640, 90]]<|/det|> A car takes 15 minutes to travel along a road that is \(20\mathrm{km}\) long. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 434, 117]]<|/det|> What is the average speed of the car? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 737, 145]]<|/det|> A \(0.75\mathrm{km / h}\) B \(5.0\mathrm{km / h}\) C \(80\mathrm{km / h}\) D \(300\mathrm{km / h}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 174, 96, 192]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 174, 707, 191]]<|/det|> Which statement about the mass and the weight of an object is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 202, 687, 219]]<|/det|> A They are both affected by changes in the acceleration of free fall. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 228, 330, 244]]<|/det|> B They are both forces. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 364, 270]]<|/det|> C They have different units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 714, 297]]<|/det|> D Weight is calculated by dividing mass by the acceleration of free fall. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 324, 99, 343]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 324, 636, 341]]<|/det|> Two objects P and Q are placed in a beaker containing a liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 500, 370]]<|/det|> Object P floats in the liquid and object Q sinks. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 732, 401]]<|/det|> Which row for the densities of object P, object Q and the liquid is possible? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 707, 558]]<|/det|>
density of object P
g/cm³		density of object Q
g/cm³		density of liquid
g/cm³
A1.20.60.8
B1.21.41.0
C11.38.913.6
D11.319.313.6
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 586, 96, 604]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 580, 603]]<|/det|> The diagram shows some liquid in a measuring cylinder. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 363, 632]]<|/det|> The mass of the liquid is \(16\mathrm{g}\) . <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 643, 555, 825]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 838, 387, 854]]<|/det|> What is the density of the liquid? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 865, 744, 882]]<|/det|> A \(0.80g / cm^3\) B \(1.25g / cm^3\) C \(36g / cm^3\) D \(320g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 890, 90]]<|/det|>
A spacecraft is travelling in space with no resultant force and no resultant moment acting on it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 521, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the spacecraft is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 353, 148]]<|/det|>
A Its direction is changing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 303, 174]]<|/det|>
B It is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 351, 199]]<|/det|>
C Its speed is decreasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 343, 225]]<|/det|>
D Its speed is increasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 96, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 552, 270]]<|/det|>
A man holds a short ladder in four different positions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 284, 687, 300]]<|/det|>
The weight of the ladder causes a moment about the man's shoulder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 460, 329]]<|/det|>
In which position is the moment greatest?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 341, 892, 540]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 564, 96, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 564, 803, 581]]<|/det|>
A hole is drilled in a square tile. The diagram shows the tile hanging freely on a nail.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 441, 610]]<|/det|>
Where is the centre of mass of the tile?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 622, 655, 820]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 434, 88]]<|/det|> Which source of energy is renewable? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 100, 191, 115]]<|/det|> **A** coal <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 126, 248, 141]]<|/det|> **B** natural gas <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 152, 176, 167]]<|/det|> **C** oil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 178, 195, 193]]<|/det|> **D** wind <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 223, 107, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 223, 627, 240]]<|/det|> A student does work by pulling a box across a horizontal floor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 528, 269]]<|/det|> She now pulls a second box along the same floor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 702, 299]]<|/det|> Which row indicates that the student is now doing twice as much work? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 530, 457]]<|/det|>
force used to pull boxdistance the box is pulled
Ais doubledis doubled
Bis doubledis halved
Cstays the sameis doubled
Dstays the sameis halved
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 485, 107, 503]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 919, 517]]<|/det|> Air is trapped in a closed tube by a thread of mercury. The mercury thread is \(100 \text{mm}\) long. The tube is held as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 528, 605, 708]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 721, 420, 737]]<|/det|> Atmospheric pressure is \(770 \text{mm Hg}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 750, 445, 766]]<|/det|> What is the pressure of the trapped air? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 778, 750, 795]]<|/det|> **A** \(100 \text{mm Hg}\) **B** \(670 \text{mm Hg}\) **C** \(770 \text{mm Hg}\) **D** \(870 \text{mm Hg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 796, 90]]<|/det|>
Brownian motion is the random motion of particles due to molecular bombardment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 574, 120]]<|/det|>
In which states of matter is Brownian motion observed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 356, 149]]<|/det|>
A gases, liquids and solids

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 338, 175]]<|/det|>
B gases and liquids only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 330, 201]]<|/det|>
C gases and solids only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 336, 226]]<|/det|>
D liquids and solids only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 907, 271]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the relative number of molecules in a liquid that have a given kinetic energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 284, 900, 300]]<|/det|>
The graph is divided into sections so that each section contains the same number of molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 313, 907, 330]]<|/det|>
From which section does the greatest number of molecules escape from the liquid per unit time?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[233, 342, 760, 497]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 526, 107, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 526, 918, 558]]<|/det|>
An electric kettle heats some water. The same kettle then heats a different liquid. The temperature of the liquid rises more rapidly than the temperature of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 571, 522, 587]]<|/det|>
What is a possible explanation of this difference?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 600, 800, 616]]<|/det|>
A The liquid condenses on the cooler parts of the kettle less than the water does.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 626, 600, 643]]<|/det|>
B The liquid expands more than the water as it heats up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 567, 669]]<|/det|>
C The liquid has a lower boiling point than the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 679, 618, 695]]<|/det|>
D The liquid has a smaller thermal capacity than the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 757, 90]]<|/det|> A wooden wheel can be strengthened by putting a tight circle of iron around it. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[317, 100, 677, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 242, 650, 259]]<|/det|> Which action would make it easier to fit the circle over the wood? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 271, 332, 287]]<|/det|> **A** cooling the iron circle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 298, 332, 313]]<|/det|> **B** heating the iron circle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 324, 586, 340]]<|/det|> **C** heating the wooden wheel and cooling the iron circle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 698, 366]]<|/det|> **D** heating the wooden wheel but not heating or cooling the iron circle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 395, 107, 413]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 395, 755, 412]]<|/det|> A student wishes to calibrate a mercury-in-glass thermometer with a \(^\circ \text{C}\) scale. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 425, 801, 441]]<|/det|> Which values should she use for the lower fixed point and for the upper fixed point? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 453, 656, 581]]<|/det|>
lower fixed pointupper fixed point
Amelting point of iceboiling point of mercury
Bmelting point of iceboiling point of water
Cmelting point of mercuryboiling point of mercury
Dmelting point of mercuryboiling point of water
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 610, 107, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 610, 918, 643]]<|/det|> Four thermometers, with their bulbs painted different colours, are placed at equal distances from a radiant heater. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 656, 881, 672]]<|/det|> Which thermometer shows the slowest temperature rise when the heater is first switched on? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 684, 242, 700]]<|/det|> **A** matt black <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 711, 242, 725]]<|/det|> **B** matt white <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 737, 248, 751]]<|/det|> **C** shiny black <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 763, 248, 777]]<|/det|> **D** shiny white

Ripples are produced on the surface of the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 406, 120]]<|/det|> What causes the ripples to refract? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 141, 149]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 131, 593, 148]]<|/det|> The cold water in the tank is replaced by warm water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 141, 176]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 158, 715, 175]]<|/det|> The ripples change speed as they move from deep to shallow water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 141, 202]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 184, 435, 201]]<|/det|> The ripples hit the wall of the tank. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 141, 228]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 210, 477, 227]]<|/det|> The ripples pass through a narrow gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 255, 107, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 920, 287]]<|/det|> The diagrams show a wave on the surface of the water in a tank at times 1.0s apart. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 853, 90]]<|/det|> A student measures the potential difference across a device and the current in the device. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 552, 120]]<|/det|> Which calculation gives the resistance of the device? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 400, 148]]<|/det|> **A** current + potential difference <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 160, 400, 175]]<|/det|> **B** current ÷ potential difference <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 187, 400, 202]]<|/det|> **C** potential difference ÷ current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 214, 400, 228]]<|/det|> **D** potential difference × current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 256, 107, 274]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 918, 288]]<|/det|> A lamp is connected across one cell, then across two cells. The potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp and the current in it are measured in each case. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 306, 317]]<|/det|> The results are shown. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[307, 332, 692, 425]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 439, 918, 471]]<|/det|> What is the change in the resistance of the lamp when the number of cells is increased from one to two? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 354, 500]]<|/det|> **A** It decreases by \(0.015\Omega .\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 511, 327, 526]]<|/det|> **B** It increases by \(1.5\Omega .\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 539, 327, 553]]<|/det|> **C** It increases by \(2.3\Omega .\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 322, 580]]<|/det|> **D** It increases by \(17\Omega .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 652, 90]]<|/det|>
An electrical heater transfers thermal energy to the surroundings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 780, 120]]<|/det|>
The graph shows how the amount of thermal energy transferred varies with time.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[274, 129, 724, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 344, 588, 361]]<|/det|>
The heater continues to transfer energy at the same rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 374, 693, 391]]<|/det|>
How much thermal energy is transferred by the heater in 5.0 minutes?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 724, 419]]<|/det|>
**A** 200J **B** 400J **C** 2000J **D** 12 000J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 448, 107, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 580, 465]]<|/det|>
Which electrical component does the symbol represent?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 475, 576, 513]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 528, 207, 544]]<|/det|>
**A** a fuse

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 245, 571]]<|/det|>
**B** a relay coil

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 581, 255, 597]]<|/det|>
**C** a thermistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 607, 303, 623]]<|/det|>
**D** a variable resistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 354, 90]]<|/det|> A student sets up this circuit. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 102, 608, 214]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 231, 400, 248]]<|/det|> What is the purpose of the circuit? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 260, 631, 278]]<|/det|> **A** to allow a lamp to be made dimmer or brighter as required <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 287, 405, 304]]<|/det|> **B** to amplify the sound of a voice <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 364, 330]]<|/det|> **C** to light a lamp in the dark <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 339, 505, 356]]<|/det|> **D** to sound a bell when the temperature rises <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 384, 107, 402]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 744, 402]]<|/det|> The diagram shows two voltmeters P and Q connected to a potential divider. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 412, 666, 543]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 553, 725, 570]]<|/det|> The sliding connection at point X is moved towards the top of the diagram. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 584, 611, 601]]<|/det|> What happens to the reading on P and to the reading on Q? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 515, 743]]<|/det|>
reading on Preading on Q
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 770, 107, 788]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 770, 663, 787]]<|/det|> A simple electric generator induces an electromotive force (e.m.f.). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 800, 568, 817]]<|/det|> Which modification would increase the induced e.m.f.? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 828, 616, 846]]<|/det|> **A** Increase the number of turns in the coil of the generator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 855, 572, 872]]<|/det|> **B** Increase the distance between the magnetic poles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 881, 624, 898]]<|/det|> **C** Reduce the strength of the magnetic field around the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 907, 505, 924]]<|/det|> **D** Reverse the direction of the magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 774, 91]]<|/det|> A transformer has \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) turns in the primary coil and \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) turns in the secondary coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|> Which row gives the values of \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) and \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) for a transformer that steps up a voltage of \(1200\mathrm{V}\) to \(36 000\mathrm{V}\)? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 395, 273]]<|/det|>

A2 00060 000

D600 0002 000

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 863, 90]]<|/det|> In the atomic model, an atom consists of a central mass, orbited by much smaller particles. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 101, 692, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 265, 663, 282]]<|/det|> What is the name of the central mass and of the orbiting particles? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 295, 485, 424]]<|/det|>
central massorbiting particles
Aneutron\(\alpha \)-particles
Bneutronelectrons
Cnucleus\(\alpha \)-particles
Dnucleuselectrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 305, 107, 323]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 556, 322]]<|/det|> Radioactive materials must be handled in a safe way. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 384, 352]]<|/det|> What is **not** a safety procedure? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 153, 381]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 365, 540, 381]]<|/det|> Monitor exposure time to radioactive materials. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 153, 407]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 392, 542, 407]]<|/det|> Store radioactive materials in cardboard boxes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 153, 434]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 418, 515, 434]]<|/det|> Use tongs to pick up the radioactive source. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 358, 460]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 444, 359, 460]]<|/det|> Wear protective clothing. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 840, 919, 870]]<|/det|> Permission to reproduce items where third-party owned material protected by copyright is included has been sought and cleared where possible. Every reasonable effort has been made by the publisher (UCLES) to trace copyright holders, but if any items requiring clearance have unwittingly been included, the publisher will be pleased to make amends at the earliest possible opportunity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 879, 919, 908]]<|/det|> To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer-related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge International Examinations Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet.
